div.p: Iacke Drums Entertainment: OR THE COMEDIE Of Pasquill and Katherine. As it hath bene sundry times plaide by the Children of Powles.
AT LONDON Printed for Richard Oliue, dwelling in Long Lane. 1601.

body.head: ❧ IOHN DRVMS Entertainment, or the Comedie of Pasquill and Katherine.

sp.p: IN good faith Gentlemen, I thinke we shall be forced to giue you right Iohn Drums entertainment, for hee that composde the Booke, we should present, hath done vs very vehement wrong, he hath snatched it from vs, vpon the very instance of entrance, and with violence keepes the boyes from comming on the Stage. So God helpe me, if we wrong your delights, tis infinitly against our endeuours, vnles we should make a tumult in the Tyring-house.

sp.l: You much mistake his Action Tyer-man,
His violence proceeds not from a minde
That grudgeth pleasure to this generous presence,
But doth protest all due respect and loue
Vnto this choise selected influence.
He vowes, if he could draw the musick from the Spheares
To entertaine this presence with delight,
Or could distill the quintessence of heauen
In rare composed Sceanes, and sprinkle them
Among your eares, his industry should sweat
To sweeten your delights: but he was loth,
Wanting a Prologue, & our selues not perfect,
To rush vpon your eyes without respect:
Yet if youle pardon his defects and ours,
Heele giue vs passage, & you pleasing sceanes,
And vowes not to torment your listning eares
With mouldy fopperies of stale Poetry,
Vnpossible drie mustie Fictions:
And for our parts to gratifie your fauour,
Weele studie till our cheekes looke wan with care,
That you our pleasures, we your loues may share.

div.head: ACTVS PRIMVS.
div.stage: Enter Iacke Drum, and Timothy Twedle, with a Taber and a Pipe.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Come Timothy Twedle, tickle thy Pipe on the greene, as I haue tipled the Pot in the Seller, and the hoy for the honor of High-gate, you old Troian.

sp.speaker: Twedle.
sp.p: And a heigh for the honor of Hygate, Hem, by my holydam, tho I say it, that shuld not say it, I think I am as perfect in my Pipe, as Officers in poling, Courtiers in flattery, or wenches in falling: Why looke you Iacke Drum, tis euen as naturall to me, as brawdry to a Somner, knauery to a Promoter, or damnation to an Vsurer. But is Holloway Morice prancing vp the hill?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p:
I, I; and Sir Edward, and the yeallow toothd, sunck-eyde, gowtie shankt Vsurer Maman, my young
Mistresses and all are comming to the greene, lay Cushions, lay the Cushions, ha the wenches!

sp.speaker: Twed.
sp.p: The wenches, ha, when I was a yong man and could tickle the Minikin, and made them crie thankes sweete Timothy, I had the best stroke, the sweetest touch, but now (I may sigh to say it) I am falne from the Fidle and betooke me to thee.

div.stage: Enter Sir Edward Fortune, M. Mamon, Camelia, Katherine, and Winifride, Camelias maide.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Sit M. Mamon, ha heeres a goodly day nigh.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, and faith what newes at court?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.stage:
What newes at court? ha, ha, now Iesu God,
Fetch me some Burdeux wine, what newes at court?
Reprobate fashion, when each ragged clowt,
Each Coblers spawne, and yeastie bowzing bench,
Reekes in the face of sacred maiestie
His stinking breath of censure, Out-vpont, He drinkes.
sp.l: Why by this Burdeux iuice, tis now become
The shewing-horne of Bezelers discourse,
The common foode of prate: what newes at court?
But in these stiffe nekt times when euery Iade
Huffes his vpreared crest, the zealous bent
Of Councellors solide cares is trampled on
By euery hacknies heeles: Oh I could burst
At the coniectures feares, preuentions
And restles tumbling of our tossed braines:
Ye shall haue me an emptie caske thats furd
With nought but barmy froath, that nere traueld
Beyond the confines of his Mistresse lippes,
Discourse as confident of peace with Spaine,
As if the Genius of quick Machiauel
Vsherd his speech.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Oh forbeare, you are too sharpe with me.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.l: Nay M. Mamon, misinterpret not,
I onely burne the bauen heath of youth,
That cannot court the presence of faire time
With ought but with, what newes at Court sweete sir?
I had rather that Kemps Morice were their chat,
For of foolish actions, may be theyle talke wisely, but of
Wise intendments, most part talke like fooles.
The summe is this, beare onely this good thought,
The Counsell-chamber is the Phaenix nest,
Who wastes it selfe, to giue vs peace and rest.

div.stage: The Taber and Pipe strike vp a Morrice. A shoute within. A Lord, a Lord, a Lord, who!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh a Morice is come, obserue our country sport,
Tis Whitson-tyde, and we must frolick it.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Skip it, & trip it, nimbly, nimbly, tickle it, tickle it, lustily,
Strike vp the Taber, for the wenches fauor, tickle it, tickle it, lustily:
Let vs be seene, on Hygate Greene, to daunce for the honour of Holloway.
Since we are come hither, lets spare for no leather,
To daunce for the honour of Holloway.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Wel said my boyes, I must haue my Lords liuory, what ist, a May-pole? troth twere a good body for a courtiers imprezza, if it had but this life, Frustra florescit. Hold Couzen hold.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Thankes Couzen, when the Lord my Fathers Audit comes, weel repay you again. Your beneuolence too sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: What a Lords sonne become a begger?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Why not, when beggers are become Lordes sonnes, come tis but a small trifle.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Oh sir, many a small make a great.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: No sir, a fewe great make a many small, come my Lords, poore and need hath no lawe.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.p: Nor necessitie no right, Drum downe with them into the Celler, rest content, rest content, one bout more and then away.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Speake like a true heart, I kisse thy foote sweet knight.

div.stage: The Morice sing and daunce, and Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir Edward Fortune you keep too great a house,
I am your friend, in hope your sonne in lawe,
And from my loue I speake, you keep too great a house,
Go too you do, yon same dry throated huskes
Will suck you vp, and you are ignorant
What frostie fortunes may benumme your age,
Pouertie, the Princes frowne, a ciuile warre, or.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.l: Or what? tush, tush, your life hath lost his taste,
Oh madnes still to sweate in hotte pursuite
Of cold abhorred sluttish nigardise,
To exile ones fortunes from their natiue vse,
To entertaine a present pouertie,
A willing want, for Infidell mistrust
Of gratious prouidence: Oh Lunacie,
I haue two thousand pound a yeare, and but two Girles,
I owe nothing, liue in all mens loue,
Why should I now go make my selfe a slaue
Vnto the god of fooles; put worst: then heer's my rest.
I had rather liue rich to die poore, then liue poore to die rich.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Oh but so great a masse of coyne might mount from wholsome thrift, that after your decease your issue might swell out your name with pompe.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.l: Ha, I was not borne to be my Cradles drudge,
To choake and stifle vp my pleasures breath,
To poyson with the venomd cares of thrift
My priuate sweet of life: onely to scrape
A heap of muck, to fatten and manure
The barren vertues of my progeny,
And make them sprowt, spight of their want of worth:
No, I do loue my Girles should wish me liue,
Which fewe do wish that haue a greedy Syre:
But still expect and gape with hungry lip,
When heele giue vp his gowtie stewardship.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You touch the quick of sence, but then I wonder
You not aspire vnto the eminence
And height of pleasing life: to Court, to Court,
There burnish, there spread, there stick in pompe
Like a bright Diamond in a Ladies browe,
There plant your fortunes in the flowring spring,
And get the sunne before you of respect:
There trench your selfe within the peoples loue,
And glitter in the eye of glorious grace,
What's wealth without respect and mounted place?

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.l: Worse and worse, I am not yet distraught,
I long not to be squeasd with mine owne waight:
Nor hoyse vp all my sailes to catch the winde
Of the drunke reeling Commons: I labor not
To haue an awfull presence, nor be feard
(Since who is feard, still feares to be so feard)
I care not to be like the Horeb Calfe,
One day ador'd, and next pasht all in peeces:
Nor do I enuy Poliphemian puffes,
Swizars slopt greatnes: I adore the Sunne,
Yet loue to liue within a temperate zone,
Let who will climbe ambitious glibbery rowndes,
And leane vpon the vulgars rotten loue,
I'le not coriuall him: The Sunne will giue
As great a shadow to my trunck as his:
And after death like Chesmen hauing stood
In play for Bishops, some for Knights, and Pawnes,
We all together shall be tumbled vp, into one bagge,
Let hush'd calme quiet, rock my life a sleepe:
And being dead, my owne ground presse my bones,
Whilest some old Beldame hobling ore my graue,
May mumble thus: Here lies a knight whose money
Was his slaue. Now Iack what newes?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: And please your Wor. the Morice haue tane their liquor.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Hath not the liquor tane them?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Tript vp their heeles or so? one of them hath vndertaken to daunce the Morice from Hygate to Holloway on his heeles, with his hands vpwards.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.p: Thats nothing hard.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Yes sir, tis easier for him to daunce on his head than his heeles, for indeed his heeles are turnde rancke rebels, they wil not obey, but they are tumbling downe the hill a pace.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And I must after then, farwel my soules delight,
Sweete Katherine adieu. Camelia goodnight.

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.p: Nay not to London Sir to night, Ifaith at least stay supper.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p:
Harke you sir, theres but two Lambes, a dozen Capons, halfe a score couple of Rabbots, three Tartes, and foure Tansies, for supper, and therfore I beseech you
giue him Iacke Drums entertainment: Let the Iebusite depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Why Iacke, is not that sufficient?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: I for any Christian, but for a yawning vsurer tis but a bit, a morsell, if you table him, heele deuoure your whole Lordship, hee is a quicksand, a Goodwin, a Gulfe, as hungry as the Iawes of a Iayle, hee will waste more substance then Ireland souldiers: A Die, a Drabbe, and a paunch-swolne Vsurer, deuoure whole Monarchies: Let him passe sweete knight, let him passe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Peace knaue peace.
Daughter, lay your expresse commaundement vpon the stay of maister Mamon, what tis womens yeere,
Dian doth rule, and you must domineere.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No sheele not wish my stay, oh I am curst
With her inexorable swiftnes, by her loue
Which dotes me more then new coynd glowing gold,
The vtmost bent of my affection
Shootes all my fortunes to obtaine her loue,
And yet I cannot praise, but stil am loathde.
My presence hated, therfore Mamon downe,
Farewell sir Edward, farewell beauties Crowne.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Faith as it please you for going, and her for wooing,
I will enforce neither.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: With your pardon sir, I shall sooner hate my selfe,
Then loue him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Nay be free my daughters in election,
Oh, how my soule abhorres inforced yokes,
Chiefly in loue, where the affections bent:
Should wholy sway the Fathers kind consent.
Foregod when I was batcheler, had a friend,
Nay had my Father wisht me to a wife,
That might haue lik'd mee, yet their very wish
Made me mistrust my Loue had not true course,
But had some sway from dutie which might hold
For some slight space: but ô when time shall search
The strength of loue, then vertue, and your eye,
Must knit his sinewes: I chusde my selfe a wife
Poore, but of good dissent, and we did liue
Till death diuorc'd vs, as a man would wish:
I made a woman, now wenches make a man:
Chuse one either of valour, wit, honestie, or wealth,
So he be gentle, and you haue my heart,
I faith you haue: What, I haue land for you both,
You haue loue for your selues. Heeres M. Mamon now.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: A club-fisted Vsurer.

sp.speaker: Sir. Ed.
sp.p: A wealthie, carefull, thriuing Citizen.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Carefull, I, I, let nothing without good blacke and white, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: A litle backe winde, sauing your wor. sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: I am scoft at, wheres my man there ho?

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sir you need not take the pepper in the nose,
Your nose is firie enough.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: What Flawne, what Christopher, Hart where's the knaue become? Hold sirrah carry my cloake.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.p: It seemes he can scarce carry himselfe.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Hee's ouer the shooes, yet heele hold out water, for I haue liquor'd him soundly.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Why cannot you come where headie liquore is, but you must needs bouze?
What a man may leade a horse to the water, but heele chuse to drinke.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.p: True, but I am no horse, for I cannot chuse but drinke.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: A pale weake stripling, yet contend with Ale.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Why the weakest go to the Pot still.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: That Iest shall saue him. Sir Edward now good day.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Nay sir, weele bring you a litle of the way.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Rely on me Christopher, I will be thy staffe,
And thy Masters nose shalbe thy lanthorn & candlelight

div.stage: Exeunt all. Manent Camelia and Winifride.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Mistresse Camelia, me thinkes your eye
Sparkles not spirit as twas wont to doo.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: My mind is dull, and yet my thoughts are fixt
Vpon a pleasing obiect, Brabants loue.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Indeed yong Brabant is a propper man,
And yet his legges are somewhat of the least:
And faith a chitty well complexioned face,
And yet it wants a beard: A good sweet youth,
And yet some say he hath a valiant breath,
Of a good haire, but oh, his eies, his eies.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Last day thy praise extold him to the skies.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Indeed he wares good cloaths, & throws his cloak
With good discretion vnder his left arme,
He curles his boote with iudgement, and takes a whiffe
With gracefull fashion, sweares a valorous oath,
But ô the diuel, hath a hatefull fault, he is a yonger brother.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: A yonger brother? ô intollerable.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: No Mistresse, no: but theres M. Iohn,
M. Iohn Ellis, theres a Lad Ifaith,
Ha for a vertuous honest good youth!

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Tut he is good, because he knows not how to be bad,
Nor wherefore he is good.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: I know not, mee thinkes not to be bad, is good enough in these daies.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Nay he is a foole, a perfect Idiot.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Why all the better. And I'le tell you this,
The greatest Lady in the Land affects him,
Nay doates vpon him, I, and lies with him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: What Lady, good sweet Winifride, what Lady say? Faith there be some good parts about the foole, which I perceiue not, yet an other may: what Lady, good sweet Winifride? say quick good wench.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: The Lady Fortune.

sp.speaker: Camel.
sp.p: Why my name's Fortune too.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.l: Then you must needs fauour him,
For Fortune fauours fooles.

sp.speaker: Camel.
sp.p: Oh but to hugge a foole is odious.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.l: Foule water quencheth fire well inough,
And with more liuely pallor, you shall taste
The Iuyce of pleasures fount at priuate times:
Pish, by my maiden-head, were I to match,
I would elect a wealthy foole fore all,
Then may one hurry in her Chariot,
Shine in rich purpled Tissue, haue hundred loues,
Rule all, pay all, take all, without checke or snib.
When being maried to a wise man (O the Lord)
You are made a foole, a Ward, curbd and controlld, and (O) out vpon't.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Beleeue me wench, thy words haue fired me,
I'le lay me downe vpon a banke of Pinkes,
And dreame vppont; Sweete foole, I tis most cleare,
A foolish bed-mate, why he hath no peere.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, her loue is as vncertaine as an Almanacke, as vnconstant as the fashion, Iust like a whiffe of Tabacco, no sooner in at the mouth, but out at the nose: I thinke in my heart I could make her enamoured on Timothy Twedle: wel he that fees me best, speeds best. For as it pleasd my bribed lippes to blowe,
So turnes her feathry fancie too and fro.

div.stage: Enter Brabant iunior at one doore, Ned Planet at the other.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Good speed thee my good sweet Planet,
How doest thou Chuck?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: How now Brabant, where haue you liu'de these three or foure dayes?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ho at the glittering Court my Pytheas.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Plague on ye Pytheas, what haue you done there?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Why lane in my Ladies lap, eate, drink, & sleep.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So hath thy Ladies Dog done, what art in loue
With you Hygate Mammer still?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Still, I still, and still, I in eternitie.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.p: It shall bee Cronicled next after the death of Bankes his Horse, I wonder why thou lou'st her?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Loue hath no reason.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Then is loue a beast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: O my Camelia is loue it selfe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: The diuel she is: Hart her lips looke like a dride Neats-tongue: her face as richly yeallow, as the skin of a cold Custard, and her mind as setled as the feet of bald pated time.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Plague on your hatefull humor, out vppont,
Why should your stomacke be so queasie now,
As to bespawle the pleasures of the world?
Why should you run an Idle counter-course
Thwart to the path of fashion? Come your reason?
O you are buried in Philosophie,
And there intombd in supernaturalls,
You are dead to natiue pleasures life.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p:
Let me busse thy cheeke sweete Pugge,
Now I am perfect hate, I lou'd but three things in the world, Philosophy, Thrift, and my self. Thou hast made me hate Philosophy. A Vsurers greasie Codpeece made me loath Thrift: but if all the Brewers Iades in the town can drug me from loue of my selfe, they shall doo more then e're the seuen wise men of Greece could: Come, come, now I'le be as sociable as Timon of Athens.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Along with me then, you droning Sagbut,
I'le bring thee to a Crewe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Of Fooles wilt not?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Faith if you haue any waight of iudgement, you may easily sound what depth of witts they drawe, theres first my elder brother.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Oh the Prince of Fooles, vnequald Ideot,
He that makes costly suppers to trie wits:
And will not stick to spend some 20. pound
To grope a gull: that same perpetuall grin
That leades his Corkie Iests to make them sinke
Into the eares of his Deryders with his owne applause.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Indeed his Iests are like Indian beefe, they will not last, and yet he powders them soundly with his own laughter.
Then theres the Gotish French-man, Mounsieur Iohn fo de King, knowste thou him?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Oh, I to a haire, for I knew him when he had neuer a haire on his head.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: He is a faithfull pure Rogue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I, I, as pure as the gold that hath bene seuen times tryed in the fire.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Then theres Iohn Ellis, and profound toungd Maister Puffe, he that hath a perpetuitie of complement, he whose phrases are as neatly deckt as my Lord Maiors
Hensmen, he whose throat squeakes like a treble Organ, and speakes as small and shrill, as the Irish-men crie Pip, fine Pip.

And when his period comes not roundly off, takes tole of the tenth haire of his Bourbon locke: as thus. Sweete Sir, repute me as a (Puffe) selected spirit borne to be the admirer, of your neuer inough admired (Puffe).

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Oh we shall be ouerwhelmd with an invndation of laughter. Come, where are they?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Here at this Tauerne.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: In, in, in, in, I long to burst my sides and tyer my spleene with laughter.

div.stage: Enter two Pages, the one laughing, the other crying.

sp.speaker: Page. 1.
sp.p: Why do'st thou crie?
Why do'st thou laugh?
I laugh to see thee crie.

sp.l: And I crie to see thee laugh.
Peace be to vs. Heres our Maisters.

div.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Planet, Brabant Iunior, Iohn Ellis, M. Puffe, and Mounsieur Iohn fo de King.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: You shall see his humour, I pray you bee familiar with this Gentleman maister Puffe, he is a man of a well growne spirit, richly worth your. I assure you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Sir I enrowle you in the Legend of my (Puffe) intimates, I shall be infinitely proud if you will daigne to value me worthy the embracement of your (Puffe) better affection.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Speake you from your thought sir?

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: I, or would my silke stocke should loose his glosse else, I shall triumph as much in the purchase of your (Puffe) loue, as if I had obtained the great Elixar: Let vs incorporate our affections I pray you: let me be forward in your fauour.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Sir, I pray you let me beg you for a Foole.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.l: I affect no rudenes gentlemen, the heauens stand
Propitious to your faire designes:
Assoone as next the sun shall gin to shine,
I will salute the eies of Katherine.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.l: Of Katherine, M. Planet obserue the next,
M. Iohn, what makes you so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: I do not vse to answere questions.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: What are you thinking on now?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I do not vse to thinke.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: He lookes as demurely as if he were asking his Father blessing.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I do not vse to aske my Father blessing.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: Hart, how chaunce he is out of his similies?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I haue followed Ordinaries this twelue month, onely to finde a Foole that had landes, or a fellow that would talke treason, that I might beg him. Iohn, be my Ward Iohn, faith Ile giue thee two coates a yeare and be my Foole.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.l: He shall be your Foole, and you shall be his
Coxe-come. Ha, ha, I haue a simple wit, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I shall crowe o're him then.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Is there not one M. Iohn Ellis here?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: There sits the thing so calde.

sp.speaker: Br. Sig.
sp.l: Now to the last course: Monsieur Iohn fo de King,
I will helpe you to a wench Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: No point, a burne childe feere de fire.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As a hungry dogge waiteth for a mutton bone, or as a tatterd foote-boy for a cast sute, euen so will I attend on my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: O my Vinifride, pree you awe, by gor, me ang de for her.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Nay stay, stay, I will helpe you to a dilicate plump-lipt wench.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Toh, phi, phi, your proffer ware stink: stay Vinifride; or by gor die, me die, me die by gor, me ang so desirous adiew goot Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Oh stay Mounsieur, how do you pronounce Demurra? Ha, ha, Ile plague him.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Grand Sot, my vench is gone, & me brule, and me brule, like one mad bule, me go into de vaterto coole my reine, ang my back made de vater hize againe, dus so brule, me burst vor a vench, and yet grand poc on you all, pree you adiew.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As the Iigge is cald for when the Play is done, euen so let Mounsieur goe.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee, me teach you much French vor dis, I goe to Hygate, adiew grand Sors.

sp.speaker: Ellis
sp.p: As sore eyes cannot endure the Sun, nor scabd hands abide salt water, so must I leaue all, and see my mistresse, and as faire Ladies do vse soule foyles, euen so do I bid you farewell.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Why this is sport imperiall, by my Gentry, I would spend fortie Crownes, for such an other feast of fooles. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: I wonder who would be the foole then?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Why tis the recreation of my Intellect, I thinke I speake as significant, ha, ha, these are my zanyes, I fill their paunches, they seed my pleasures, I vse them as my fooles faith, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Tis a generous honour.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Troath I thinke you haue a good wit, ha? pray you sup with me, I loue good wits, because mine owne is not vnfortunate: pray you sup with me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Ile giue God thankes sir, that hath sent a foole to feed me.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Come along then, ye shall haue a Capon, a Tansey, and some kick-showes of my wits, ha, ha, some toyes of my spirit.

div.stage: Exit Bra. Sig. and Bra. Iunior.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I will eate his meate, and spend's money, thats all the spight I can do him: but if I can get a Pattent for concealed Sots, that Dawe shall troupe among my Ideots.

div.head: ACTVS SECVNDVS.
div.stage: Enter M. Puffe with his Page.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: Boy whats a Clocke?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Past three, and a faire morning.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.l: Burnes not that light within the sacred shrine?
I meane the chamber of bright Katherine.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I, should appeare by these presence, that it doth.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: I wonder that the light is vp so soone.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: O Mistresse Snuffe was weary with sleeping in the Socket, and therefore hath newly put on her stamell petticoat, & taken her pewter state to giue light to things are in darknesse.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: And I know that women of grauitie and sweetnes are soone vp.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I see that women of leuitie and lightnesse, are soone downe.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.l: Boy cleare thy throate, and mount thy sweetest notes
Vpon the bosom of this sleeke cheekt aire:
That it may gently breathe them in the eare
Of my adored Mistresse: Come begin.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Delicious beautie that doth lie
Wrapt in a skin of Iuorie,
Lie stil, lie stil vpon thy backe,
And Fancy let no sweete dreames lacke
To tickle her, to tickle her with pleasing thoughts.
But if thy eyes are open full,
Then daine to view an honest gull,
That stands, that stands, expecting still
When that thy Casement open will
And blesse his eyes, & blesse his eyes, with one kind glance.

div.stage: The Casement opens, and Katherine appeares.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: All happinesse and vnconceiu'd delight,
Waite on the loue of sweet fac'de Katherine.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Good youth Amen: I do returne your wish
With ample interest of beatitude.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: I do protest, with ceremonious (puffe) lippes
The purest blood of my affection,
Is euen fatally predestinate
To consecrate it selfe vnto your (puffe) loue.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Vnto my loue? Oh sir you binde me to you:
Faire Gentleman I haue a thankfull heart,
Tho not a glorious speech to sweet my thankes.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Reward my loue then with your kinder loue.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: With my loue sir, I relish not your speech.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: I with your loue, in pleasing marriage.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Alas sir, cannot be my Loues a man,
Who hardly can requite the deare protests
Of kind affection, which you seeme to vowe
Vnto his fortunes: kind youth, you did wish
All happinesse to wayt vpon my loue:
Well he shall know it when we next do meete,
And thanke you kindly: now good morrow sweete.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: You take my, my, my meaning (puffe.)

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay if he be puffing once, the fire of his wit is out.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Why she is gone. Hart did I rise for this?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She cannot endure puffing. O you puft her away

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Lets slink along vnseen, tis yet scarse day.

div.stage: Enter Mamon with Flawne, bearing a light before Mamon.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.p: Now me thinks I hold the candle to the diuel.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Put out the light, the day begins to breake.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.p: Would the day and thy neck were broke togither.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Oh how the gout and loue do tyre me.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Why sir, loue is nothing but the very gout.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: As how Flawne? as how?

sp.speaker: Flawne
sp.p: Thus sir: Gout and loue, both come with Idlenesse, both incurable, both humorous, onely this difference: the Gout causeth a great tumor in a mans legges, and loue a great swelling in a womans belly.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p:
Why then ô Loue, ô Gout, ô goutie Loue, how thou torments olde Mamon: good morrow to the
sweet lipt Katherine, eternall spring vnto thy beauties loue.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Alas good aged Sir, what make you vp?
In faith I pittie you, good soule to bed,
Troth soone youle crie, Oh God my head, my head.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No Katherine, the wrinckling print of time
Err'd, when it seald my forehead vp with age:
I haue as warme an arme to entertaine
And hugge thy presence in a nuptiall bed,
As those that haue a cheek more liuely red:
And tho my voice be rude, yet Flawne can sing
Peans of beautie, and of Katherine.
List to the Musicke that corrupts the Goddes,
Subuerts euen Desteny, and thus it shogges.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Chunck, chunck, chunck, chunck, his bagges do ring
A merry note with chuncks to sing:
Those that are farre more yong and wittie,
Are wide from singing such a Dittie
As Chunck, chunck, chunck,
Theres Chunck that makes the Lawier prate,
Theres Chunck that make a foole of Fate:
Theres Chunck, that if you will be his,
Shall make you liue in all hearts blis.
With Chunck, chunck, chunck.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Tis wel sung good old man, hence with your gold,
Leaue the green fields tis deawy; youle take cold.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: The Casements shut, wel here Ile lurke & stay,
To see who beares the glorie of the day.
Hence, hence, to London, Flawne let me alone.

sp.speaker: Flawne
sp.p: I can hardly leaue him alone, for the Diuell and double Duckats, still associate him, but I am gone.

sp.speaker: Pasquil.
sp.l: The glooming morne with shining Armes hath chaste
The siluer Ensign of the grim cheekt night,
And forc'd the sacred troupes of sparkling starres
Into their priuate Tents, yet calme husht sleepe
Strikes dumbe the snoring world: yet frolick youth
Thats lately matcht vnto a well shapte Lasse,
Clippes his sweet Mistresse, with a pleasing arme,
Whilst the great power of Imperious Loue
Sommons my dutie to salute the shine
Of my Loues beauties. Vnequald Katherine
I bring no Musick to prepare thy thoughts
To entertaine an amorous discourse:
More Musick's in thy name, and sweet dispose,
Then in Apollos Lyre, or Orpheus close.
I'le chaunt thy name, and so inchaunt each eare,
That Katherinas happie name shall heare.
My Katherine, my life, my Katherine.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: My Ned, my Pasquil, sweet I come, I come,
Euen with like swiftnes, tho not with like heart:
As the fierce Fawcon stoupes to rysing fowle
I hurrey to thee: do not goe away,
The place is priuate, and tis yet scarce day.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Oh these kind words imparadize my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ha, ha, yong Pasquil haue I found you out?
Ist you must bore my nose, Ile bore your heart:
Why this same boy's as bare as naked Truthe.
A lowe ebd gallant, yet sheele match with him:
Ile match him, if his skin be ponyard proofe.
He may scape the force of gold and murder, if not,
As you returne sir, I will pepper you.
And art thou come deare hart, first fee be this,
This kinde imbrace, and next this modest kis.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: This is no kisse, but an Ambrosian bowle,
The Nectar deaw of thy delicious sowle:
Let me sucke one kisse more, and with a nimble lip,
Nibble vpon those Rosie bankes, more soft and cleare
Then is the Ieweld tip of Venus eare.
Oh how a kisse inflames a Louers thought,
With such a fewell let me burne and die,
And like to Hercules so mount the skie.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: Come you grow wanton. Oh you bite my lip.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: In faith you Iest, I did but softly sip
The Roseall Iuice of your reuiuing breath:
Let clumsie iudgements, chilblaind gowtie wits
Bung vp their chiefe content within the whoopes
Of a stuft dry Fatt: and repose their hopes
Of happinesse, and hearts tranquilitie,
Vpon increase of durt: but let me liue
Clipt in the cincture of a faithfull arme,
Luld in contented ioy, being made diuine,
With the most precious loue of Katherine.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Let the vnsanctified spirit of ambition
Entice the choyse of muddy minded Dames
To yoke themselues to swine, and for vaine hope
Of gay rich trappings, be still spurd and prickt
With pining discontent for nuptiall sweetes.
But let me liue lou'd in my husbands eies,
Whose thoughts with mine, may sweetly simpathize.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: The heauens shall melt, the sun shall cease to shine,
Before I leaue the loue of Katherine.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Nay when heauens melted, & the sun strooke dead,
Euen then my loue shall not be vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: When I turne fickle, vertue shall be vice.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: When I proue false, Hell shall be Paradice.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: My life shall be maintaind by thy kind breath.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: Thy loue shall be my life, thy hate my death.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Oh when I die let me imbrace thy waste.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: In death let me be counted thine and chaste.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Heauens graunt, being dead my soule may liue nie thee

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: One kisse shal giue thee mine eternally.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: In faire exchaunge vouchsafe my hart to take.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: With all my mind, weare this Ned for my sake,
But now no more, bright day malings our loue,
Farewell, yet stay, but tis no matter too,
My Father knowes I thinke, what must ensue.
Adieu, yet harke, nay faith, adieu, adiew.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Peace to thy passions, till next enterview.

div.stage: Enter Mamon, and Mounsier Iohn fo de King.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Now Mounsieur be but confident, and hold
There is the price of blood, this way he comes,
Strike home bold arme, and thou shalt want no crowns.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Feare you noting, when he is die, me bring you word. Exit Mamon.
Hee, by gor braue crowne, braue monney,
Me haue here a patent to take vp, one, two, treescore
Vench: fine Crowne, fine vench, vnreasonably fine,
Dis monney is my baude. Me send a French crowne
To fetch a fine vench, de French crowne fetch de
Fine vench, de fine vench take de French crowne,
And giue me de French poc. Hee excellent, you see
Mee kill a man, you see mee hang like de Burgullian,
Hee no poine: Hee by Gor, mee haue much vitt,
Ang me much bald, and me ang much bald wit.
Here come de Gentleman metre Pasquill.

sp.speaker: Pasquill.
sp.l: Ist possible that sisters should so thwart
In natiue humours? one's as kind and fayre,
As constant, vertuous, and as debonayre,
As is the heart of goodnesse: the other, proud,
Inconstant, fantasticke, and as vaine in loues,
As trauellers in lies: blest Katherine,
Camelia's not thy sister, if she bee,
Shees basterd to the sweetes that shine in thee.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Boniour Metre Pasquill, sance Iest, me am hired to kill you, Mounsieur Mamon, Messier: Iounck, Iounck, giue me money to stab you, but me know there is a God that hate bloud, derfore, me no kil, me know dere is a vench, that loue Crowne, derefore me keepe de money.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Vnhallowed villaine, that with gold and bloud, Thinkes that almighty loue can be withstood.

Hold Mounsieur, there are more Crownes, onely do this, returne to Mamon, tell him the deed is done, and bring him hither, that he may vainely triumph in my bloud, I haue some painting which I found by chaunce in loose Camelias chamber, with that Ile staine my breast, go and returne with speed.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee, by gor I smell a rat, me flie, me flie, by gor.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Leaud miscreant, that through the throat of hel,
Wouldst mount to heauen, and enioy loue,
Invaluably pretious: no rancke churle,
Thou wast not made to slauer her faire lips
With thy dead rewmy chops, nor clip her waste,
With thy shrunke bloudlesse arme, I heare him come.
Now Pasquill faigne, ô thou eternall light,
Mourne that thy creatures should in bloud delight.

div.stage: He lies downe, and faines himselfe dead.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Now smug fac'd boy, now nibble on her lips,
Now sippe the deawe of her delitious breath.
Stinke, rot, damne, bake in thy cluttered bloud,
Snakes, Toads, and Earwigs, make thy skull their neast,
Ingendring deaw-wormes, cling orethwart thy breast.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Hush, hush, leaue praying for dead, tis no good
Caluianisme, puritanisme. Dissemble, here are company.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Good morrow Sir, who lies there murdred?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen, the kindest vertuous youth
That e're adorned London. Damned theeues
To spoile such hopes: the last words that he spake,
Sticks still within the hollow of mine eare.
Katherine quoth he, hold M. Mamon deare,
I know not what he meant, but so he said.
If that you passe to Hygate, tell the Knight,
Pasquill is sunke into eternall night.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Faith twas a good youth, come Brabant, come away.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Dead Kate, dead Kate, dead is the boy,
That kept rich Mamon from his ioy.

div.stage: Mamon sings. Lantara, &c. Pasquill riseth, and striketh him.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Oh the diuell, the ghost of Pasquill, I am dead, if you haue any curtesie in you, beleeue it. I beleeu'd you when you faign'd, beleeue me now, for I am almost dead, numbd vp with feare, giue faith sweete gentle youth.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Old wretch, amend thy thoughts, purge, purge, repent,
Ile hide thy vlcer, be but penitent.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Ha, I think twas but his ghost that swept along.
Grand sot Mamon, Pho, phy, phy, phy, a foutra pour vos chunck, chunck. Iohn fo de King, teach you a ding, Iohn fo de King graund Sot, Sot, Sot.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Death, plague, and hell, how is curst Mamon vext?
Scourgde with the whip of sharpe derision:
Ile home, and starue, this crosse, this peeuish hap,
Strikes dead my spirits like a thunderclap.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Gods pretious, I forgot to bring my Page,
To breathe some Dittie in my Mistris eare.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Wouldst haue a Ballet to salute her with?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: No, but a Song. How wouldst thou court thy Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Why with the world, the flesh & the diuel.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Right dog, well thoult sweare, that I am blest
Beyond infinitie of happinesse,
When thou beholdest admired Camelia.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: And God wold blesse me with 3. such mistresses,
I would giue two of them to the diuel, that hee would take the third.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh when she clips, and clings about my necke,
And suckes my soule forth with a melting kisse.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Doth she vse thee so kindly then, ha?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O I, and calls me deare, deare Brabant, and (ô Iesu God)
I cannot expresse her sweets of entertaine,
Sheele so insinuate with chaste amorous speech,
And play the wanton with such pretie grace,
And vowes loue to me: Oh I'le make thee madde
To see how gratious Brabant's in her eye.
Here is her window, marke but when I call,
How swift she comes, and with what kind salutes
She welcomes me. What ho Camelia?
Faith youle be tane vp, what in bed so late?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: And you take her vp Brabant, sheele take you downe.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Hart they heare not: My Camelia wake?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: What harsh vnciuil tongue keeps such a coile?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Winifride tis I. Tell my sweet Duck I am here,
Now marke Ned Planet, now obserue her well.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Shee wonders at your rudenesse that intrudes
Vpon the quiet of her mornings rest,
And shee's amaz'de, that with such impudence
You dare presume to intimate some loue to her,
As if she knew you more then for a youth,
A yonger brother, and a stipendary.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Now mark Ned Planet, now obserue her kindnes.
Good morrow M. Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As the Countrey mayd crieth to her Cowe to milke her, or as the Trauailer knocketh with his Hostes for a reckning, euen so do I call to thee ô Mistris.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sweet Iohn my Loue, heer's thy Camelia:
Hold weare this fauour, with this kisse vppont.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Flesh and blood cannot beare such disgrace.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, helpe, helpe, he boxes mee that hee doth. Helpe, helpe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Edward, Katherine, Drum, and Twedle.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: What outrage haue we here so early vp?
Sir you do wrong the quiet of my house. Enter Camelia.
I faith you do, and tis but rudely done,
Go too tis not. Is this a place to brawle?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: And please thee knight, I'le tell thee faith & troth.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: What did he strike thee sweet?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I in good deed law, and a my conscience, I thinke he hath made my nose bleede.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: And would not you draw your weapon out, and to it lustily, as long as you could stand?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I do not vse to drawe.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Did he giue thee a box on the eare, and wouldst thou take it?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: And he be such a foole to giue it me, why should not I be so wise as to take it.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Pure honestie, kinde Ducke, kisse me sweet Iohn.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: Hart Sir Edward, will you suffer this?
Now on my life she is enamord on the fooles bable.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Go too sir boy forbear, you wrong my Loue,
And you forget your selfe to vse such Iests,
Such nastie rybauldry vpon my daughter:
I tell you M. Brabant, doth she loue
Any that meriteth the name of man?

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: Why hee's no man, but a very—

sp.speaker: S. Ed.
sp.l: Well, well, no more; my house, my self, my loue,
Opens their hearts with liberall imbrace
To entertaine your presence: I or any mans
So they'le be ciuile, modest, not prophane,
Not like to those that make it their chiefe grace,
To be quite graceles.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Well said honest knight,
We haue had blood enough to day alreadie:
Ned Pasquil's slaine by bloodie murdering Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Speak softly, God forbid, my daughter heares,
Tell me the circumstance, I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Eternall death vnto my happinesse,
My Pasquil slaine? Oh God, oh God, oh God.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I, and I thinke the Vsurer made a Tent
Euen of his nose it was so red and neere:

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: God for his mercy, what mischance is heere?
A good youth, a vertuous modest youth,
I faith he was. And I can tell your sir,
My daughter Katherine, where is she now?
Whithers she gone? Drum call her hither straite.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Your Drum wil sound a call sir presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: And as I told you sir, my daughter Katherine
Affected him right dearly: by my peace of soule,
If he had liu'd, I could haue hartily wisht
He had bene my sonne in lawe, I faith I could:
But see the will of God. How now Drum,
Where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Sir, she is either inuisible, or deafe, for I can neither see her, nor she heare mee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Boddie of mee, my heart misgiues me now,
Looke, call, search, run all about.
My daughter gone? Go all and search her out.
Heer's Pasquil ha? Is this the man thats dead?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Let me intreat this fauour, do not search
Or be inquisitiue why I fain'de:
Repute me worthie your better censure: and thus think
My cause was vrgent, the rest lie buried.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Well, I would you had not fainde.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Why would you haue had me dead indeed?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Oh no, but I haue lost my child I feare,
By your strange faining, she no sooner heard
The tydings of your death, but gone she was,
And God knowes whither. Ha what newes now?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Tis easier to finde wit in ballating, honestie in Brokers, Virginitie in Shordich, then to heare of my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Broach me a fresh Butt of Canary Sacke,
Lets sing, drink, sleep, for thats the best reliefe:
To drowne all care, and ouerwhelme all griefe.
Powre Wine, sound Musick, let our bloods not freeze,
Drinke Duch like gallants, lets drinke vpsey freeze.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Edward, Planet, Brabant, Drum & Twedle.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Seruant youle go in too, and stay dinner?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: I in truthe, for as the Itch is augmented
By scratching, so is my loue by seeing my mistresse.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: How's this, how's this, My Katherin gone hence?
Sences awake, and thou amazed soule
Vnwinde thy selfe from out the Labyrinth
Of gaping wonder, and astonishment.
My Katherine departed? how? which way?
Foole, foole, stand not debating, but pursue
Haste to her comfort, for from thee doth spring
(Wretch that thou art) her cause of sorrowing.

div.head: ACTVS TERTIVS.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, tipsie, tipsie, tipsie, all turnd whirlegig, Iohn fo de king, Drum, and Timothy Twedle, are rare fine, ha for the heauens, Ifaith: Drums Lyon drunk, and he dings the pottes about, crackes the glasses, swaggers with his owne shadow. Honest Timothy is Mawdelin drunke, and he weepes for kindnesse, and kisses the hilts of Iacke Drums Dagger. Mounsieurs Goat drunke, and he
shrugges, and skrubbes, and hees it for a wench. Heere they come reeling, I must packe, or we shall swagger, for they hauing a cracke in their heades, and I a fault in my hands, we shall nere agree.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: A Seruingman quoth you? Hart, and if I serue any thats flesh and blood, would I might ne're taste my liquore more: stand bare whilest hee makes water, out vppont, Ile to Ireland, and there Ile Tan, ran, ty, ry, dan, Sa, sa, sa, sa: Nay tis the onely life.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Nay good Thewte hart, good kind Iack, stay, if you would loue mee, as I loue you, we would liue & die together: and please God, would I were dead, and you are gone. And heeres M. Iohn so de king, a verie honest man too.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: I, I, hee's a verie good honest man: for theres not a haire betwixt him and heauen.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Heele liue with vs now & teach vs French.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: I by my trot, ang you helpe mee to a Vench now, mee teach you French. 5. towsand, towsand yere, ô your Secke is hote, and make mee brule, and brule, and burne, for a (hee) by gor your Seck is hote.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Welcome Basilisco, thou wilt carry leuell, and knock ones braines out with thy pricking wit. Kisse me sweet wench, kisse mee.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee my Vinifride, by gor you are come, in te very nick to pleasure mee, pree you kisse mee, clip mee, loue mee, or by gor mee ang die certaine.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Out you French Dogge, touch my Loue, and Ile—

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Touch her, by gor mee touch her, and touch her, and touch her.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Ile touch you, Ile slash you, Ile vench ye.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Put vp, put vp, for the passion of God put vp, or if youle needs too it, sheath both your weapons in mee first.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Hart touch my loue, touch my Winifride?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Hark you Iacke, come to my chamber an houre hence, and you shall haue what you will aske, and I can graunt.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Why then my chollers down. Iohn fo de King. Foutra for you.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Foutra for me, futtra, futtra, futtra, fiue towsand futtra's for you.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Stay friend Iacke, Ile reele along with you, if youle not swagger.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Sweete, sweete Mounsieur, hang you slaues, I loue you infinitely.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By gor me teach you French foure towsand yeare dan.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Well Mounsieur, I'le giue you pleasure.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: But will you presently? quickly, for by gor me am a hot shot.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: I so they say, I heard you were vnder the Torred zone last day.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Pish tis no matter, me am like a Tabacco Pipe, de more me am burne, de cleaner me am.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Well then, two houres hence come to my chamber, and Timothy Twedle shall giue you mee in a sacke.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: In a sacke? Ha very well.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: And you shall carrie me to my Maisters house at Holloway, for in the house we cannot be priuate without suspect. Till then, farewell.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot vnreasonablie good, I carrie de vench on my backe, and devench carie me on her (hee) fine backe, fine vench, fine Mounsieur, fine, fine, fine Knight, all fine, vnreasonablie fine, me sing vor ioy; by gor me sing la, liro, liro la, lilo.

div.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Brabant Iunior, and Planet.

sp.speaker: Bra Sig.
sp.p: Gentlemen, as e're you lou'd wench, obserue M. Puffe and me.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: What shall we obserue you for?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Oh for our complement.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Complement, whats that?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Complement, is as much as (what call you it) tis deriued of the Greeke word, a pox ont.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Complement, is as much as what call you it, tis deriued of the Greeke word, a pox ont.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: You shall see M. Puffe and me tosse it, Ifaith marke with what grace I encounter him.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Hart thy brother's like the Instrument the Merchants sent ouer to the great Turke: you need not play vpon him, heele make musicke of himselfe, and hee bee once set going.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: M. Puffe, I long to do faire seruice to your loue.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: Most accomplisht wit, exquisitly accoutred, (Puffe) Iudgement, I could wish my abilitie worthie your seruice, and my seruice worthie your abilitie.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: By the Lord fustian, now I vnderstand it: complement is as much as fustian.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: I protest your abilities are infinite, your perfections matchlesse, your matchlesse perfection infinite in abilitie, and your infinite abilitie, matchlesse in perfection.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Good againe, reioyce Brabant, thy brother will not liue long, he talkes Idlely alreadie.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Delicious spirit, disparage not your courtesie, stand not bare to him that was borne to honor you.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Let vs presse our haires then, with an vniforme consent.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: The pressure of my haires, or the puncture of my heart, standes at the seruice of your sollide perfections: my life is bound to your loue, your loue being my life, tho my life bee not worthie your loue, your perfection is the center to which all the paralels of my affection are drawne: your loue my life, your perfection, my affection, being—

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Your Asse, my Foole.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Being chainde by the mightie coplet of ineuitable destenie, who seeth the sunne, but hee must adore it: who seeth beautie, but he must honour it: who vieweth gold, but he must couet it: then, (ô then) who can behold your sun-like beauteous golden beauties, but he must more then adore, much more then honour, and most infinitely loue to be out, out, out.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: Out he is indeed.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Hee's at a stand, like a restie Iade, or a Fidler, when he hath crackt his Minikin.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Outragiously addicted to the worthie pursuite of such matchlesse worth.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Sir, I can rest but truly thankfull, for your more then good conceit of my no lesse then litle worth. And now fir for the consequent houres of the day; how stands your intencion for imployment?

sp.speaker: Puff:
sp.p:
I ha tane my leaue of Sir Edward, bid adiew to loue, my Mistresse is gone, my humour is spent, my ioyes are at an end, and therefore Gentlemen, I leaue
loue, and fall to the (puffe) Lawe, I will interre my selfe in Ploydens Coffin, and take an eternall Conge of the world. And so sweete gallants farewell.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Nay Ile follow you to your graue. Gentlemen youle not accompany the coarse?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: No, no, looke Ned Brabant, yons a pleasing obiect for thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: My Mistresse is turnde Bucephalus, no bodie must ride her but Alexander: no bodie kisse her but Iohn Ellis. Now stand and list good Planet.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come sweetest Loue, lets giue time pleasing wing,
What shall we make some purposes or sing?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I will sing, so you will beare my burthen.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come laie thy head then in my virgin lappe,
And with a soft sleeke hand Il'e clappe thy cheeke,
And wring thy fingers with an ardent gripe:
Ile breathe amours, and euen intraunce thy spirit,
And sweetly in the shade lie dallying.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Now dally sport and play, This merry month of May,
This is the merry, mery month, Sweet time for dallying:
The Birds sit chirping, chirping, The Doues sit billing, billing,
Phillip is treading, is treading, is treading, is treading, is treading,
All are to pleasures willing.
You that are faire and wittie, Obserue this easie Dittie,
And leaue not Natures Natures blisse; Do not refuse to kisse.
The Birds sit chirping, chirping, The Doues sit billing, billing,
Phillip is treading, is treading, &c.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: Death I can holder: Life of loue
Amazing bewtie, let not me seeme rude,
Tho thus I seeme to square with modestie.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pray you let me go, for heele begin to square, And euen as some doo weare Muffes for warmth, some for wantonnesse, some for pride, some for neither, but to hide gowtie fingers, so will I get your Fathers consent, and marry you. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sir it were good you got a benefice,
Some Evenuch'd Vicaridge, or some Fellowship,
To prop vp your weake yonger brothership.
Match with your equalls, dare not to aspier
My seate of loue, I wis Sir, I looke higher.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: Astonishment of Nature, be not proud
Of Fortunes bounties: Brabant is a man,
Tho not so clogd with durt as others are:
I do confesse my yonger brothership;
Yet therein laie no such disparagement
As your high scorne imputes vnto my worth.
Coach Iades and Dogges, are coupled still together,
Only for outward likenes, growth and strength,
But the bright models of eternitie,
Are ioind together for affection,
Which in the soule is form'de. Oh let this moue,
Loue should make mariage, and not mariage Loue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Wooe her no more Brabant, thou'lt make her proud,
You Duch Ancient why should you looke higher?
His births as good as yours, and so's his face:
Put off your Iengle, Iangles, and be not as faire,
He shall renounce it, fore this Audience,
Put off your cloathes, and you are like a Banbery cheese,
Nothing but paring: why should you be proud,
And looke on none but Weathercocks forsooth?
O you shall haue a thousand pound a yeare!
Bar Ladie thats a bumming sound. But harke,
Wilt therefore be a slaue, vnto a slaue,
One thats a bound Rogue vnto Ignorance?
Well thou'lt serue to make him gellide broaths,
And scratch his head, and may be now and then
Heele slauer thee a kisse. Plague on such mariages.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Rude vnciuile Clowne.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Tut raile not at me, turn your eie vpon the leprosie of your own iudgement, loath it, hate it, scorn it, and loue this yong Gentleman, who is a Foole in nothing but in louing thee: madde in nothing but affecting thee: and curst in eternitie if he marry thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Sir you ha spoke exceeding pleasingly,
For which I loue you, as I loue a dull dead eye.
Brabant I do coniure thee Court not mee,
Do not presume to loue or fancie mee.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: How not presume to loue or fancie you?
Hart, I will loue you, by this light I will
Whether you will or no, I'le loue you still.
Spight of your teeth I will your loue pursue,
I will by heauen, and so sweet soule adieu.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Farewell, and neuer view my face againe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Harke you faire Winifride, sweet gentle maide,
I haue but fained with you all this while,
I doate vpon the sweet Camelia,
And if your fauour will but second me,
I vowe when I shall wed Camelia,
To indowe you with a hundred pound a yeare,
And what I haue shall stand at your commaund.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Sir I wil vndertake to forward your faire loue,
So you'le remember what you here do vowe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If I forget it, heauen forget mee:
Do you but praise me, let not her once know
I loue, or do affect her for the world.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Well feare no rubbes, farwell faire bounteous Sir.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: It workes, it workes, magnificent delight,
Laughter, triumph, for ere the Sunne go downe,
Thy forehead shall be wreath'd, with pleasures crowne.

div.stage: Enter Pasquil at one doore, and his Page at the other.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Now my kinde Page, canst thou nor heare, nor see,
Which way my Katherine hath bent her steppes?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir I can.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What canst thou my sweet Page?
What canst thou Boy?
Oh how my soule doth burne in longing hope,
And hangs vpon thy lippes for pleasing newes.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: What? ô how my hart doth quake & throb with feare.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir I can tell you nothing of her in good faith.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Oh thou hast tortur'de me with lingring hope,
Go haste away, flie from the pestilence
Of my contagious griefe, it will infect thee boy,
Murder thy youth, and poison thy lifes ioy.
Run search out Katherine, in her eies dwell
Heauens of ioy; but in Pasquil hell.
Oh thou omnipotent, infinitie,
Crack not the sinewes of my patience
With racking torment: Insist not thus to scourge
My tender youth with sharpe affliction,
If I do loue that glorie of thy hand,
That rich Idea of perfection,
With any lustfull or prophane intent,
Crost be my loue, murdred be all my hopes:
But if with chaste and vertuous arme I clip
The rarest modell of thy workemanship,
Be then propitious: ô eternall light,
And blesse my fortunes, maugre hellish spight.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Black sorrow, nurse of plaints, of teares, & grones,
Evaporate my spirit with a sigh,
That it may hurrey after his sweete breath,
Who made thee doate on life, now hunt for death.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What soule is that, that with her teare-full eies
Seemes to lament with me in miseries?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Here seemes to be the pressure of his truncke,
Deare earth confirme my doubt, was this the place
Which the faire bodie of my Pasquil prest,
When he laie murdred? See the drooping grasse
Hangs downe his mourning head, and seemes to say
This was the fatall place, where Pasquil lay.
Oh thou sweet print, stampt by the fairest limbes,
The richest Coffin of the purest soule
That euer prest the bosome of the earth,
First drinke my teares, and next sucke vp my blood.
Now thou immortall spirit of my Loue,
Thou pretious soule of Pasquil view this knife
Which once thou gauest me, and prepare thy arme
To clip the spirit of thy constant Loue.
Deare Ned I come, by death I will be thine,
Since life denies it to poore Katherine.

div.stage: She offers to stabbe her selfe.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Hold, hold, thou miracle of constancie,
First let heauen perish, and the crazde world runne
Into first Chaos of confusion,
Before such cruell violence be done
To her faire breast, whose fame by vertue wonne,
Shall honour women whilste there shines a sunne.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Thrice sacred spirit, why dost thou forsake
Elizeum pleasures, to withhold the arme
Of wretched Katherine? Oh let me die,
Retire sweete Ghoast, do not pollute thy hand
With touch of mortalls.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Amazement of thy Sex, Pasquill doth liue,
And liues to loue thee in eternitie.
Be not agast, recouer spirit, (Sweete)
Tis Pasquill speakes, tis Pasquill clips thy waste,
Tis Pasquill prints a kisse on thy faire hand.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: What do I dreame? or haue I drawne the sluce
Of life vp? and through streames of bloud
Vnfelt, haue set my prisoned soule at large?
Am I in heauen? or in Pasquills Armes?
I am in heauen, for my Neds embrace
Is Katherines long wish'd celestiall place.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Diuinitie of sweetnesse, I protest,
If these inferiour Orbs were rowled vp,
And the imperiall heauen bar'd to my view,
Twere not so gracious, nor so much desir'd,
As my deare Katherine is to Pasquills sight.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: Heauen of Content, Paphos of my delight.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Mirrour of Constancie, life-bloud of loue.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: Center to whom all my affections moue.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Renown of Virgins, whose fame shal ne're fleet.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Oh I am maz'd with ioy, I pree thee sweete,
Vnfold to me, what sad mischaunce it was,
Forc'd thy deaths rumour, and such woes disperc'd?
Sad sorrow past, delights to be rehearsed.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: It will be tedious, but in breefe thinke thus,
Old Mamons malice was the venombd foame,
That poisoned all the sweets of our content.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Alas deare heart, that loue should be so crost.
Now good Ned fetch my gowne, tis at yon house,
I would be loth to turne to Hygate thus.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I am oblig'de with infinit respect, to do you seruice.
Oh power diuine, was euer such a loue as Katherine?

sp.speaker: Ent. Ma.
sp.l: Looke Mamon, search Mamon, this way shee went,
Put on thy spectacles, this way she went:
Blest, blest, blest, be thy natiuitie,
Yonder she sits, Ile either haue her now,
Or none shall e're enioy her with content.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: How loues impatient, when will Ned returne?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Tut, tis no matter when, looke where thy Mamon is.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Good diuel, for Gods sake do not vexe my sight:
Didst not thou plot the death of my deare Loue?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and wold complot ten thousand deaths,
Euen damne my soule, for beauteous Katherine.
My ship shall kemb the Oceans curled backe
To furnish thee with braue Abiliaments,
Rucks of rich Pearle, and sparkling Diamonds
Shall fringe thy garments with Imbroadry:
Thy head shall blaze as bright with Orient stone,
As did the world being burnt by Phaeton.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: You make me death, for pitties sake forbeare:
Oh when will Pasquil come? Good Sir depart.
When wilt returne? I pray you Sir goe hence,
And troth, I will not hate you: nay I'le speake
Against my heart, and say I loath you not.
You vexe my patience, gentle sir forbeare,
I begge it on my knee, and with a teare.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Tut will you loue me, and detest yon boy?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: Heauen detest me first, and loathe my soule.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Is it your finall resolution?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: God knowes it is. So good Sir rest content.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I, I will rest, and thou shalt rest thus blur'd,
Thus poysond; venomde with this oyle of Toades:
If Mamon cannot get thee, none shall ioy
Which he could not enioy. I feare no lawe,
Gold in the firmest conscience makes a flawe.
Rot like to Helen: Spittle hence, adiew,
Let Pasquil boast in your next interview.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Be pittifull and kill me gentle Sir.
Heauen my heart is crackt with miserie:
Where shall I hide me? which way shall I cleanse
The eating poyson of this venomde oyle?
Poore wretch (alas) see where thy Pasquil comes.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Here Loue put on your gown. How now? good God,
Heauen giue me patience: who hath vs'd thee thus?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: The diuel in the shape of Mamon. Sweet
Touch me not. Pasquil I coniure thee now
By all the power of affection,
By that strickt bond of loue that lincks our hearts,
Leaue and abandon me eternally.
I merit now no loue, yet prethee sweet,
Vouchsafe to giue me leaue to loue thee still.
But I do binde thee by thy sacred vowe
Of our once happie, and thrice blessed loue,
Follow not Katherine: good Ned, doo not greeue,
In time iust heauen may our woes releeue.

sp.speaker: Pas. fureus.
sp.l: O dira fata, saeua, miseranda, horida
Quis hic Locus? quae Regio? quae Mundi plaga?
Vbi sum? Katherina, Katherina, Eheu Katherina.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: My Spectacles will betraie mee, looke
Mamon, search Mamon, here abouts they fell.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Welcome Erra Pater, you that make Prognostications for euer. Where's you Almanacke?

div.stage: Pulles his Indentures out of Mamons bosome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Lorde blesse my Obligations, Lorde blesse my bonds, Lord blesse my Obligations. Alas, alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Let me see sir now, when will true valour be at the full? Oh theres an opposition tis eclipsed, Venus, I Venus is mounted. Wheres the Goat now? Kembd, fine kemd. Oh heere are Dog daies, out vpont Dog dayes, Dog dayes, Dog dayes, out vpont.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Alas my Obligations, my Bonds, my Obligations, my Bonds. Alas, alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Katherina, Katherina, Ehew Katherina.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Obligations, Obligations: Alas my Obligations, I am vndone, vndone, vndone.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: What sir you for, you Dog, you Hounde, you
Crust, whats best newes with you now? Out-alas my
Obligations, my Bonds, I am vndon, vndon.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Sir, the best newes is, your ship (the Hopewell) hath hapt ill, returning from Barbary. Tis but sunk, or so, not a scrap of goods sau'de.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Villaines, Rogues, Iewes, Turkes, Infidels, my nose will rot off with griefe. O the Gowt, the Gowt, the Gowt, I shall run mad, run mad, run mad.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Amen, amen, amen. But theres other newes to comfort you withall sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Lets heare them good Flawne. My shippe, my bonds, my bondes, my ship, I shall run mad vnlesse thy good newes reclaime mee. Lets heare thy newes.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Your house with all the furniture is burnt, not a ragge left, the people stand warming their handes at the fire, and laugh at your miserie.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: I defie heauen, earth and hell, renounce my nose, plague, pestilence, confusion, famine, sworde and fire, deuoure all, deuoure me, deuoure Flawne, deuoure all: bondes, house, and ship, ship, house, and bondes, Dispaire, Damnation, Hell, I come, I come, so roome for Mamon, roome for Vsury, roome for thirtie in the hundred. I come, I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Why me thinkes this is right now, Ile euen laie him vp in Bedlame, commit him to the mercie of the whip, the entertainment of bread and water, and the the sting of a Vsurers Conscience for euer.

div.head: ACTVS QVARTVS.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Truly Mistresse Winifride, as I would be willing to be thankfull, and thankfull to finde you willing to prostrate your faire partes to my pleasure, so I hope you will remember your promise, and promise what you now remember, if you haue forgot, I would be glad to put you in minde of it.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Truly friend Iohn, as I would be loth to breake my promise, so I would be vnwilling to keepe my word to the dishonesting of my virginitie. Marry for a nights lodging or so, I wil not be strait lac'd to my friend. Therfore thus it must be. To night I must lie at the Farme at Holloway, thither shall you be conueyed in this Sacke, & laid in my chamber, from whence you shall haue free accesse to the pleasures of my priuate bed.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Well then bee constant Winifride, and you shall finde me faithfull Iacke Drum: and so taking leaue of your lippes, I betake me to the tuition of the Sacke.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Winifride my Mistresse Camelia staies for you to attend her to the Greene, I must go and clap my Tabers cheekes there, for the heauens Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Stay a little heere, and if Iohn fo de king come, giue him that Sack. Oh I could crack my Whalebones, breake my Buske, to think what laughter may arise from this.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot, dis loue is a most cleanly Ientleman, he is very full of shifte, de fine Vench, can inuent ten towsand, towsand trick to kisse a gentleman (hee) see by gor she ha keepe her word, she is in de seck alreadie, hee, braue by gor, my blood das sparkle in my veine for ioy. Metre Timotty you must giue me dat seck dere.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Owy da Mounsieur, that is well pronounced is it not?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Ritt, ritt, ritt, excellan: excellan: adew Timothy, me am almost burst for ioy.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Well, I know what the Wenches on the green are saying now, as well as if I were in their bellies, when will Timothy come, when wil honest Timothy approach, when will good Timothy drawe neare? Well Wenches now reioyce, for Timothy Twedle doth come.

div.stage: Enter Pla. Bra. Sig. and Bra. Iunior.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: Brother how like you of our moderne witts?
How like you the new Poet Mellidus?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: A slight bubling spirit, a Corke, a Huske.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: How like you Musus fashion in his carriage?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: O filthily, he is as blunt as Pawles.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.l: What thinke you of the Lines of Decius?
Writes he not a good cordiall sappie stile?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: A surreinde Iaded wit, but a rubbes on.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Brabant thou art like a paire of Ballance,
Thou wayest all sauing thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Br. Sig.
sp.l: Good faith, troth is, they are all Apes & gulls,
Vile imitating spirits, dry heathy Turffes.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: Nay brother, now I thinke your iudgement erres.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Erre, he cannot erre man, for children & fooles speake truthe alwaies.

div.stage: Enter Mounsieur with a Sacke, and Iack Drum in it.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: See who comes yonder sweating with a pack.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Mounsieur, what do you beare there ha?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Pree you away, you breake my glasses der, Ieshu, now mee know not what to doe, Zot dat I was to come dis way widd dem.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Glasses you salt rheume, come what ha you there?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Trike no more for Ieshu sake, by gor mee haue brittle vare, if you knock it, it will break presant, pre you adieu.

sp.speaker: Br. Iu.
sp.p: We must know whats in the bag Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot, mee tell you true, will you no trike me?

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: No faith, but see you tell vs true, or else.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Or els, or els by gor, do wat you please wid me: Sweet Vinifride, my verie art dus vurst, he by gor, me did not dink to vrong yow dus: come out sweet Vinifrid, me much discredit yow.
He Iack Drum. Iesu vat made you dere?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p:
Gentlemen my M. desires you to come supp with him, I was sent to inuite you, and this itching goat, would needs ease my legges & carry me: I hope you'le
come, and so I take my leaue. I, I am guld, but if I quit her not, well.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Come, there's some knot of knauery in this tricke.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: His culler is not currant, wel, let passe.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.l: Come Mounsieur, come, Ile helpe you to a
Go downe the hill before, Ile follow you. Wench,

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Me dank you: Mor deu, he mon a mee, me ame trooke dead wit greife, de cock of my humore is downe, and me may hang my selfe vor a Vench.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.p: Gentlemen will you laugh hartily now?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I, and if thou wilt play the foole kindly now.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.l: I wil strait frame the strongest eternall Iest
That e're was builded by Inuention:
My wife lies verie priuate in the Towne,
I'le bring the French man to her presently,
As to a loose lasciuious Curtezan:
Nor he, nor you, nor she, shall know the rest,
But it shall be immortall for a Iest.

sp.speaker: Bra. Iu.
sp.p: Farwel brother, we shal meet at Hygate soone.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: The wicked Iest be turnde on his owne head,
Pray God he may be kindly Cuckoled.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Carry this fauour to my Ellis straight,
I long to see him, preethe bid him come.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: I would be loth to nourish your defame,
And therefore Mistresse pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: What is thy iudgement of my Ellis chandge?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: No that is firme: but your estate is changde.
You know your sister's straungely vanished,
And now the hope and revenue of all,
Calls you his sole, and faire apparant heire:
Now therefore would I haue you chaunge your loue.
Indeed I yeeld tis moderne policie,
To kisse euen durt that plaisters vp our wants.
I'le not denie, tis worthy wits applause,
For women on whom lowring Fortune squints,
And casts but halfe an eye of due respect,
To pinne some amorous Idiot to their eyes,
And vse him as they vse their Looking-glasse,
See how to adorne their beauties by his wealth,
And then case vp the foole and lay him by.
But for such Ladies as your selfe is now,
Whose fortunes are sustaind by all the proppes
That gracious Fortune can aduance you with,
For such a one to yoake her free sweet youth
Vnto a Lowne, a Dane-like barbarous Sot,
A guilden Trunchion, fie, tis slauish vile.
Oh what is richer then content in loue?
And will you now hauing so huge a Ruck
Of heap'd vp fortunes, goe and chaine your selfe
To a dull post, whose verie eies will blaze
His base bred spirit, where so e're he comes,
And shame you with the verie name of wife.
No Mistris, no, I haue found out a man
That merits you, if man can merit you.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Lord what a tide of hate comes creeping on
Vpon my former iudgement? Come, the man?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: The man? (oh God) the man is such a man,
That he is matchlesse: oh, I shall prophane
His name, with vnrespected vtterance.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Oh thou tormentst me, deare Winifride the man?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: By the sweet pleasures of an amorous bed,
I thinke you will be deified by him.
O God the most accomplish'd man that breathes,
And Planet is the man.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Out on the diuell, there's a man indeed.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Nay looke you now, you'le straight oreshoot yourselfe,
You'le say hee's sowre and vnsociable:
Tush you know him not, that humor's forc'd:
But in his natiue spirit hee's as kinde
As is the life of loue. And then the clearest skinne,
The whitest hand, the cleanest wel shap'd legge:
The quickest eye: Fie, fie, I shall but blurre
And sulley his bright worth with my rude speech.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Well, if he court me, Ile not be much coy.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Court you? nay you must court him for ought I know:
You must not think forsoothe, that I am feed
To vrge you thus. I solemnly protest,
I motion this out of my pure vowed loue,
Which wisheth all aduancement and content
To attend the glory of your beautious youth.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O I am Planet stricken Winifride,
How shall I intimate my loue to him?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I sawe him comming vp the hill euen now,
Send him a fauour, and Ile beare it to him,
And tell him you desire to speake with him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Do, do, deare Winifride, sweet wench make haste.

div.stage: Enter Sir Edward Fortune, and Iohn Ellis, with a Paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: Sir, I haue her good will, and please you now to giue me your consent, and looke you Sir, here I haue Item'd forth what I am worth.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p:
Tush shewe me no Items, and shee loue you, a Gods name: Ile not bee curst by my daughter for
forcing her to clip a loath'd, abhorred match: and see how fortunate we are; Looke where shee stands.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: Sweet Planet, thou onely gouernst mee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Daughter giue mee your hand, with your consent, I giue you to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Marry phoh, wil you match me to a foole?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: God pardon me, not I: why M. Ellis ha?
Had you her consent, speake freely man?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Indeed law now; I thought so: by my troth
You sed you lou'de me, that you did indeed.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I as my foole, my Idiot to make sport.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Fie daughter, you are too plaine with him.
Alas my sonne Similie is out of countenance.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Truly as a Mill-horse, is not a horse Mill, and as a Cart Iade, is not a Iade Cart, euen so will I go hang my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Mary god forbid, what frolick, frolick man, weele haue a Cup of Sack and Sugar soone, shall quite expell these mustie humours of stale melancholy.

div.stage: Enter Pasquil and a Countrey Wench, with a Basket of Egges.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Is this the Egge where Castor and Pollux bred?
Ile crack the Bastard in the verie shell.

sp.speaker: Coun. Mayd.
sp.p: Alas my markets, my markets are cleane spoilde.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Vbi Hellena, vbi Troia, ist not true my Ganimede,
When shall old Saturne mount his Throane againe?
See, see, alas how bleake Religion stands.
Katherina, Katherina, you damned Titanoies,
Why prick you heauens ribbes with blasphemie?
Python yet breathes, old gray hayr'd pietie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Alas kind youth, how came he thus distraught?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I left him in pursuite of Katherine,
And found him in this straunge distemperature.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O Sir, ist you that stampe on litrature?
You are inspired you with Prophesie.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Not I, as I shall be sau'd, I am M. Iohn Ellis I.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Come, come, lets intice him by some good meanes,
Ile labour to reclaime him to his witts.
O now my daughter Katherine remembers me,
Where art thou girle? heauen giue me patience.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Poore, poore Astrea, who blurs thy orient shine?
Come yons the Capitoll of Iupiter,
Letts whip the Senate, els they will not leaue
To haue their Iustice blasted with abuse
Of flattering Sycophants. Come lets mount the Starres,
Reuerend antiquitie go you in first—
Dotage will follow. Then comes pale fac'de Lust—
Next Sodome, then Gomorha, next poore I,
By heauen my heart is burst with miserie.

div.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Mounsieur and the Page.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: I ha tell yow de very trote of the lagg Iest, by gor your England Damosells are so feere, so vittie, so kitt, by my trote shee tosse me wish vey shee please der: but pre yow were is de Vench? Is dis de house? Ha is dis de house, pre yow tell me ha?

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
sp.l: It is, it is, and shee is in the Inner Chamber:
Boy call her foorth.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: By gor den me must needs now sing,
Ding, ding, a ding, Ding a, ding a, ding,
For me am now at pleasures spring.
Ding a, ding, ding, ding a, ding a, ding a, ding,
And a hee da vench, da vench, da vench,
Which must my bruling humor quench. Coma, coma, com.

sp.speaker: Mist. Bra.
sp.p: Now sweet, you kept your promise wel last night.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By gorshe giue him much kind word already.

sp.speaker: Bra. Sig.
